newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia said unaware of aluminium cut plan.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia said unaware of aluminium cut plan.

text.p: Australian government and industry sources said they are not aware of international moves to revive the gentlemen's agreement to restrain growth in aluminium production.
David Coutts, executive director of Australia's Aluminium Development Council, said the Aluminium Council was not pushing to restrict production.

The council's members in Australia, which include the major companies, also did not know of such a move by Russia, he said. An official of the Federal government's Department of Primary Industries and Energy, who did not wish to be named but who has just returned from a visit to Europe and Russia, said she was unable to comment.
She declined to indicate whether she believed it likely that the lapsed former agreement was likely to be resurrected.
Industry sources said they were not surprised by Russia floating ideas about the resurrection of an aluminium production agreement because of the present state of the market.
Russia was exacerbating the present aluminium market slide by pumping it with low-priced product, they said.
In previous years in a similar market situation pressure grew for trade sanctions.
The Russians might be trying to get governments to talk about a new MOU before matters reached that stage, they said.
It would surprise if Canada supported a new MOU, they said.
The Canadians and Americans had been very nervous about anti-trust issues, they said.
The Australian comments follow reports that Russia would support proposals to resume the MOU between the six major world aluminium producing countries to restrain growth in aluminium production.
Countries involved at government level in the MOU were the EU, Norway, Australia, U.S., Canada and Russia.
The two-year global deal to reduce output by 10 percent was signed in March 1994 by the major producers.
